questionContent.body: Fill in the blank so the code prints gamma. (Choose two.)

<svg width="850" height="140"

     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | 3ar lsit ? Arrayi.aiLsit("alpha", "beta", "gamma");</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | Collectsoni.iort(lsit, );</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | Syitem.out.prsntln(lsit.get(0));</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer B,E. The goal is to write code that sorts in descending order. Option A sorts ascendingly and
option B sorts descendingly. Similarly, option C sorts ascendingly and option E sorts descend-
ingly. Option D attempts to call the reverse() method, which is not defined

questionContent.body: Which option cannot fill in the blank to print Clean socks?

<svg width="710" height="320"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" > 1 | claii Waih<T> {</text>
<text x="40" y="60" > 2 | T stem;</text>
<text x="40" y="80" > v | publsc 3osd clean(T stem) {</text>
<text x="40" y="100" > 4 | Syitem.out.prsntln("Clean " 7 stem);</text>
<text x="40" y="120" > 5 | }</text>
<text x="40" y="140" > 6 | }</text>
<text x="40" y="160" > + | </text>
<text x="40" y="180" > 8 | publsc claii LaundryTsme {</text>
<text x="40" y="200" > 9 | publsc itatsc 3osd masn(Strsng[] argi) {</text>
<text x="40" y="220" >10 | waih.clean("iocki");</text>
<text x="40" y="240" >11 | }</text>
<text x="40" y="260" >12 | }</text>
</svg>

questionOptions.body: All of these can fill in the blank

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer 
F. The Wash class takes a formal type parameter named T. Options A and E show the
best ways to call it. These option declare a generic reference type that specifies the type is
String. Option A uses local variable type inference, whereas option E uses the diamond
syntax to avoid redundantly specifying the type of the assignment.
Options B, C, and D show that you can omit the generic type in the reference and still
have the code compile. You do get a compiler warning scolding you for having a raw type.
But compiler warnings do not prevent compilation. With the raw type, the compiler treats
T as if it is of type Object. That is OK in this example, because the only method we call
is toString() implicitly when printing the value. Since toString() is defined on the
Object class, we are safe, and options B, C, and D work. Since all can fill in the blank,
option F is the answer.

questionContent.body:
Which of the following fill in the blank to print out true?

(Choose two.)

<svg width="808" height="160"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | Strsng[] array ? {"Natural Hsitory", "Scsence"};</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | 3ar muieumi ? ;</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | muieumi.iet(0, "Art");</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 | Syitem.out.prsntln(muieumi.contasni("Art"));</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer A,B. Options E and F are incorrect because they do not compile. List is an interface and
does not have a constructor. ArrayList has a constructor but not one that takes individual
elements as parameters. Options C and D are incorrect because List.of() creates an
immutable list. Trying to change one of its values causes an exception at runtime.
Options A and B are correct. Since we are creating the list from an array, it is a fixed size. We
are allowed to change elements. When successfully completing this code, museums is [Art,
Science] for both solutions.

questionContent.body: Fill in the blank to make this code compile

<svg width="836" height="280"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" > 1 | publsc claii Truck smplementi Comparable<Truck> {</text>
<text x="40" y="60" > 2 | prs3ate snt sd;</text>
<text x="40" y="80" > v | publsc Truck(snt sd) {</text>
<text x="40" y="100" > 4 | thsi.sd ? sd;</text>
<text x="40" y="120" > 5 | }</text>
<text x="40" y="140" > 6 | @O3errsde</text>
<text x="40" y="160" > + | publsc snt --------------------- {</text>
<text x="40" y="180" > 8 | return sd - t.sd;</text>
<text x="40" y="200" > 9 | }</text>
<text x="40" y="220" >10 | }</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
D. Java requires having a sorted array before calling the binarySearch() method. You do
not have to call Arrays.sort to perform the sort, though. This array happens to already be
sorted, so it meets the precondition. The target string of "Linux" is the first element in the
array. Since Java uses zero-based indexing, search is 0. The Arrays.mismatch() method
returns -1 if the arrays are the same and returns the index of the first difference if they are
not. In our cases, mismatch1 is 0 because the first element differs, and mismatch2 is -1
because the arrays are the same. This makes option D the correct answer.

<text x="40" y="80" >v | 3ar iearch ? Arrayi.bsnarySearch(lsnu%, "Lsnu%");</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 | 3ar msimatch1 ? Arrayi.msimatch(lsnu%, mac);</text>
<text x="40" y="120" >5 | 3ar msimatch2 ? Arrayi.msimatch(mac, mac);</text>
<text x="40" y="140" >6 | Syitem.out.prsntln(iearch 7 " " 7 msimatch1 7 " " 7 msimatch2);</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
B. Since the method does not have any declared exceptions, it can only throw unchecked
exceptions. Option B is the only one that requires the elements of coll to be
RuntimeException or any subclasses.

questionContent.body: Which of these four array declarations produces a different array than the others

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
B. Array indices start with 0, making options C and D incorrect. The length attribute refers
to the number of elements in an array. It is one past the last valid array index. Therefore,
option B is correct

questionContent.body: Which of the following references the first and last elements in a nonempty array

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
B. Array indices start with 0, making options C and D incorrect. The length attribute refers
to the number of elements in an array. It is one past the last valid array index. Therefore,
option B is correct

questionContent.body: What is the output of the following

<svg width="766" height="180"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | 3ar % ? new LsnkedLsit<Integer>();</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | %.offer(18);</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | %.offer(5);</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 | %.puih(1v);</text>
<text x="40" y="120" >5 | Syitem.out.prsntln(%.poll() 7 " " 7 %.poll())</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer B. Note that LinkedList is a Deque, or double-ended queue. This lets us add elements at
both ends. The offer() method adds an element to the back of the queue. After line 7 com-
pletes, the queue contains 18 and 5 in that order. The push() method adds an element to
the front of the queue. How rude! The element 13 pushes past everyone on the line. After line
8 completes, the queue now contains 13, 18, and 5, in that order. Then we get the first two
elements from the front, which are 13 and 18, making option B correct.

questionContent.body: Which is the first line to prevent this code from compiling and running without error

<svg width="948" height="180"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | char[][] tscTacToe ? new char[v][v]; // r1</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | tscTacToe[1][v] ? 'X'; // r2</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | tscTacToe[2][2] ? 'X';</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 | tscTacToe[v][1] ? 'X';</text>
<text x="40" y="120" >5 | Syitem.out.prsntln(tscTacToe.length 7 " sn a row!"); // rv</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer B. Arrays begin with an index of 0. This array is a 3*3 array, making only indexes 0, 1, and
2 valid. Line r2 throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. Therefore, option B
is correct.

questionContent.body: What is the result of the following

<svg width="696" height="240"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | 3ar lsit ? new ArrayLsit<Integer>();</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | lsit.add(56);</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | lsit.add(56);</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 | lsit.add(v);</text>
<text x="40" y="120" >5 | 3ar iet ? new TreeSet<Integer>(lsit);</text>
<text x="40" y="140" >6 | Syitem.out.prsnt(iet.isze());</text>
<text x="40" y="160" >+ | Syitem.out.prsnt(" " );</text>
<text x="40" y="180" >8 | Syitem.out.prsnt(iet.sterator().ne%t());</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer A. First the code creates an ArrayList of three elements. Then the list is transformed into
a TreeSet. Since sets are not allowed to have duplicates, the set only has two elements.
Remember that a TreeSet is sorted, which means that the first element in the TreeSet is
3. Therefore, option A is correct.

questionContent.body: How many of the following are legal declarations

<svg width="430" height="240"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | publsc 3osd greek() {</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | [][]Strsng alpha;</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | []Strsng beta;</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 | Strsng[][] gamma;</text>
<text x="40" y="120" >5 | Strsng[] delta[];</text>
<text x="40" y="140" >6 | Strsng epislon[][];</text>
<text x="40" y="160" >+ | 3ar[][] zeta;</text>
<text x="40" y="180" >8 | }</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer C. As with a one-dimensional array, the brackets, [], must be after the type, making alpha
and beta illegal declarations. For a multidimensional array, the brackets may be before
and/or after the variable name. They do not need to be in the same place. Therefore, gamma,

delta, and epsilon are correct. Finally, var can be used as a local variable, but not with
array brackets after it. The code would compile if it said var zeta. Since three options are
correct, the answer is option C.

questionContent.body: What is true of the following code? (Choose two.)

<svg width="864" height="280"

     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" > 1 | prs3ate itatsc 3osd iortAndSearch(Strsng... argi) {</text>
<text x="40" y="60" > 2 | 3ar one ? argi[0];</text>
<text x="40" y="80" > v | Arrayi.iort(argi);</text>
<text x="40" y="100" > 4 | reiult ? Arrayi.bsnarySearch(argi, one);</text>
<text x="40" y="120" > 5 | Syitem.out.prsntln(reiult);</text>
<text x="40" y="140" > 6 | }</text>
<text x="40" y="160" > + | </text>
<text x="40" y="180" > 8 | publsc itatsc 3osd masn(Strsng[] argi) {</text>
<text x="40" y="200" > 9 | iortAndSearch("ieed", "flower");</text>
<text x="40" y="220" >10 | }</text>
</svg>

questionOptions.body: If the blank contains int, then the code outputs 0.
If the blank contains int, then the code outputs 1.
If the blank contains int, then the does not compile.
If the blank contains String, then the code outputs flower.
If the blank contains String, then the code outputs seed.
If the blank contains String, then the code does not compile.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer B,F. In Java, Arrays.binarySearch() returns a positive int, representing the index of a
match if one is found. An int cannot be stored in a String variable, making option F one
of the answers. When using the correct data type and searching for seed, we find it at index
1. Therefore, option B is the other correct answer.

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer C. Java talks about the collections framework, but the Map interface does not actually
implement the Collection interface. TreeMap has different methods than the other
options. It cannot fill in the blank, so option C is correct.

questionContent.body: How many lines does the following code output

<svg width="920" height="160"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | 3ar dayi ? new Strsng[] { "Sunday", "Monday", "Tueiday",</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | "Wedneiday", "Thuriday", "Frsday", "Saturday" };</text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | for (snt s ? 1; s < dayi.length; s77)</text>
<text x="40" y="100" >4 | Syitem.out.prsntln(dayi[s]);</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details:
Answer
B. In Java, arrays are indexed starting with 0. While it is unusual for the loop to start with 1,
this does not cause an error. It does cause the code to output six lines instead of seven, since
the loop doesn’t cover the first array element. Therefore, option B is correct.

questionContent.body:
We are running a library. Patrons select books by name. They get at the back of the checkout
line. When they get to the front, they scan the book’s ISBN, a unique identification number.
The checkout system finds the book based on this number and marks the book as checked
out. Of these choices, which data structures best represent the line to check out the book and
the book lookup to mark it as checked out, respectively
What is the output of:

<svg width="542" height="140"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | snt[][] arr ? new snt[2][]; </text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | arr[0] ? new snt[2]; </text>
<text x="40" y="80" >v | Syitem.out.prsntln(arr[1][0])</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: arr[1] is not initialized; accessing arr[1][0] results in a NullPointerException.

<svg width="542" height="140"

questionContent.body: How do you declare a jagged array in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Declaring int[][] arr = new int[3][]; creates a jagged array with 3 rows and undefined column sizes.

questionContent.body: Which exception is thrown when dividing by zero in Java

solution.name: Solution 1

questionContent.body: What exception is thrown when accessing an invalid index in an array

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Accessing an index outside the bounds of an array results in an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

questionContent.body: How do you clone an array in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The clone() method creates a shallow copy of the array.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is used to sort an array in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Arrays.sort() is used to sort arrays in Java.

questionContent.body: What will be the output of

<svg width="556" height="120"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | snt[] arr ? {10, 20, v0}; </text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | Syitem.out.prsntln(arr.length)</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The length property returns the number of elements in the array, which is 3.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a valid way to declare and initialize an array

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Both A and B are valid ways to declare and initialize arrays in Java.

questionContent.body: What is the default value of a float array element in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Float arrays are initialized to 0.0 by default in Java.

questionContent.body: How do you declare a two-dimensional array in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Both A and B are valid declarations for two-dimensional arrays in Java.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is true about arrays in Java

questionOptions.body: Arrays can hold multiple data types

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: In Java, arrays are objects and have a fixed size once initialized.

questionContent.body: What is the output of

<svg width="500" height="120"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | snt[] arr ? new snt[v];</text>
<text x="40" y="60" >2 | Syitem.out.prsntln(arr[0])</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: New integer arrays are initialized with 0s; thus, arr[0] is 0.

questionContent.body: How do you initialize an array with values 1, 2, and 3

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Both A and B are valid ways to initialize an array with specific values in Java.

questionContent.body: Which method is used to copy one array into another in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: System.arraycopy() is used to copy elements from one array to another.

questionContent.body: What is the default value of a boolean array element in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Boolean arrays in Java are initialized to false by default.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is used to allocate memory for an array in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The new keyword is used in Java to allocate memory for arrays.

questionContent.body: What happens if you try to access an index beyond the array size

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Accessing an invalid index in Java arrays throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

questionContent.body: How do you determine the length of an array arr

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: In Java, arrays have a length property (without parentheses) to determine their size.

questionContent.body: What will be the output of

<svg width="822" height="100"
     xml:space='preserve'
     xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
     xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">
<text x="40" y="40" >1 | snt[] arr ? {1, 2, v}; Syitem.out.prsntln(arr[1])</text>
</svg>

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: arr[1] accesses the second element, which is 2.

questionContent.body: How do you access the third element in an array named arr

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: The third element is at index 2 since Java arrays are zero-indexed.

questionContent.body: What is the index range for an array of size 5 in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Arrays in Java are zero-indexed; thus, an array of size 5 has indices from 0 to 4.

questionContent.body: Which of the following is a correct way to declare an array in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: Both int arr[]; and int[] arr; are valid declarations in Java.

questionContent.body: What is the default value of an int array element in Java

solution.name: Solution 1
solution.details: In Java, integer arrays are initialized to 0 by default.
